conclusion: I'll analyze this step-by-step to find the temperature at state C.
State A: p = 3×10⁵ Pa, V = 1×10⁻³ m³
State B: p = 1×10⁵ Pa, V = 1×10⁻³ m³
State C: p = 1×10⁵ Pa, V = 3×10⁻³ m³
A to B: isovolume process (volume remains constant while pressure decreases)
B to C: isobaric process (pressure remains constant while volume increases)
Given: Temperature at state A (T₁) = 27°C = 300 K (converting to Kelvin by adding 273)
For an ideal gas, I can use the ideal gas law: PV = nRT, where P is pressure, V is volume, n is number of moles, R is the gas constant, T is temperature in Kelvin.
For the same sample of gas, n and R remain constant, so I can use the relationship: P₁V₁/T₁ = P₂V₂/T₂

premise: P₁ = 3×10⁵ Pa, V₁ = 1×10⁻³ m³, T₁ = 300 K
conclusion: nR = P₁V₁/T₁ = (3×10⁵ Pa × 1×10⁻³ m³)/300 K = 1 J/K

premise: P₃ = 1×10⁵ Pa, V₃ = 3×10⁻³ m³, nR = 1 J/K

conclusion: Verification using the relationship: P₁V₁/T₁ = P₃V₃/T₃
